headline: Pay Transparency Bill Passes Second Reading Amid Heated Economic Debates in Parliament
summary: Parliament was dominated by sharp economic clashes as the Government defended its record on jobs and infrastructure against Opposition criticism over a construction downturn and rising emigration. Amid the political sparring, two member's bills achieved significant milestones, with legislation to enhance protections for family violence victims and another to ban pay secrecy clauses both passing their second readings with cross-party support.

topicSummaries.topic: Pay Transparency Bill Passes Second Reading, Targeting Pay Secrecy
topicSummaries.content: A member's bill aimed at promoting pay fairness successfully passed its second reading with broad support, including from the National Party. The Employment Relations (Employee Remuneration Disclosure) Amendment Bill, sponsored by Labour's Camilla Belich, makes it unlawful for employers to take adverse action against employees who choose to discuss their pay. Proponents argued it is a vital tool for identifying and addressing gender and ethnic pay gaps, while opponents ACT and New Zealand First raised concerns about the sanctity of contract law.

keyExchanges.speaker: Camilla Belich (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: The intention of this bill is that people can discuss their own pay with whomever they wish, without being disciplined. It really is that simple.

keyExchanges.speaker: Dr Parmjeet Parmar (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: This is sending a very wrong message. To workplaces, trust and integrity are very important values, and this bill is actually about taking those two very important values away from workplaces, and that's why the ACT Party opposes this bill.

topicSummaries.topic: PM Clashes with Opposition Over Construction Job Losses and Youth Emigration
topicSummaries.content: During a fiery Question Time, Prime Minister Christopher Luxon faced intense scrutiny from Labour and the Greens over the state of the economy. Opposition Leader Chris Hipkins highlighted a reported loss of 15,000 construction jobs and declining builder sentiment, accusing the government of taking projects off the market. The Prime Minister deflected blame, attributing the construction downturn to high interest rates inherited from the previous government and repeatedly challenging Labour to support the government's fast-track consenting legislation to stimulate growth and create jobs.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Does he still stand by Nicola Willis' promise of fewer lanyards and more hard hats on Lambton Quay; if so, why does the Builder Sentiment report show a consistent decline in demand under his leadership, resulting in 15,000 fewer construction jobs?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, construction has been hit hard, but it's been hit hard because of high interest rates. High interest rates happened because Government spending was out of control, and you let inflation get out of control. If you really cared about all of these issues, instead of the crocodile tears, why don't you back the fast-track legislation?

topicSummaries.topic: Family Violence Victims Gain Court Protections as Bill Passes Second Reading
topicSummaries.content: Legislation to better protect victims of family violence in court passed its second reading with unanimous support from all parties. The Evidence (Giving Evidence of Family Violence) Amendment Bill, sponsored by Labour's Dr Tracey McLellan, creates an automatic presumption that victims can give evidence through alternative means, such as via video link or behind a screen, rather than having to face their abuser. The bill was refined at the select committee stage to address practical implementation concerns, ensuring it could be rolled out effectively while maintaining judicial fairness.

keyExchanges.speaker: Dr Tracey McLellan (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: At the heart of this bill is a simple but powerful shift: victims of family violence would no longer need to justify their need for protection when giving evidence in Family Court. Instead, there would be a presumption that they can give their evidence through alternative means.

keyExchanges.speaker: Tom Rutherford (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Currently, victims in Family Court don't have the same protections available to victims in criminal proceedings, and that's the intention of this bill... enable those victims in the Family Court to have the same protections that victims in criminal proceedings have.

topicSummaries.topic: PM Defends 'Bunkum' Comment on UN Letter Regarding Te Tiriti
topicSummaries.content: Prime Minister Christopher Luxon was challenged by Te Pāti Māori co-leader Rawiri Waititi over his dismissal of a United Nations letter as "total bunkum." The letter raised concerns about the Regulatory Standards Bill and its potential impact on Te Tiriti o Waitangi. The Prime Minister stood by his government's position, stating the Foreign Minister would provide an eloquent reply. Mr. Waititi questioned how Māori could hold the government accountable when it disregards advice from the Waitangi Tribunal, select committees, and now the UN special rapporteur.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rawiri Waititi (Te Pāti Māori)
keyExchanges.quote: Does he stand by his statement that the United Nations letter regarding the Regulatory Standards Bill and its impact on Te Tiriti o Waitangi is "total bunkum" and "a waste of time"?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, I think I've actually said all I want to say about that yesterday, but we've got a Minister of Foreign Affairs who's going to reply very eloquently on behalf of our Government to that letter, and I'm going to leave that to him.

topicSummaries.topic: Bill to Ban Commercial Freshwater Bottling Voted Down
topicSummaries.content: A member's bill from Te Pāti Māori co-leader Debbie Ngarewa-Packer, which sought to prohibit the commercial extraction of freshwater for bottling and on-selling, was defeated at its first reading. Ms. Ngarewa-Packer argued the bill was necessary to stop the exploitation of a precious resource by multinationals. However, it was opposed by all government coalition parties and Labour, who argued it was an ideologically driven and overly blunt measure that would undermine regional jobs and the economy, given that water bottling accounts for a minuscule fraction of total water extraction.

keyExchanges.speaker: Debbie Ngarewa-Packer (Te Pāti Māori)
keyExchanges.quote: The fact that it's an ideological approach to wai is really, I think, the ideal of us all to not allow a multinational to profit from the exploitation of our resources. That is why this bill was contained solely to making sure that those who are trying to bottle and export our wai don't get the opportunity.

keyExchanges.speaker: Mark Cameron (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: We have a full half-million cubic metres of rainfall every year in New Zealand, and, somehow, by bottling water we are going to do ourselves a disservice in New Zealand.

conclusion: Parliament advanced cross-party social legislation while remaining deeply divided over the government's economic direction and its approach to Treaty obligations.
